Quantum-Mechanics/Axioms-of-Quantum-Mech.title: Axioms of Quantum Mechanics
Quantum-Mechanics/Axioms-of-Quantum-Mech.content:
The following are the axioms of Quantum Mechanics -

The properties of quantum systems are completely defined by the specification of its state vector, denoted generally by \ket{\psi}. The state vector is an element of a complex Hilbert Space \mathbb{H}, called the space of states.
With every physical property \mathcal{A}, there exists a corresponding linear, Hermitian operator A called an observable, which acts in the Hilbert space \mathbb{H}.

The eigenvalues of these Hermitian operators are values of the physical properties.


(Born Rule) If \ket{\psi} is the vector in \mathbb{H} representing the state of the system, and \ket{\phi} represents a particular physical state of the system, we can define a probability P(\ket{\psi},\ket{\phi}) for finding \ket{\psi} in the state \ket{\phi}. This is given by,

P(\ket{\psi},\ket{\phi}  ) = |\braket{ \psi | \phi } |^{2}
Where $\braket{ \cdot | \cdot }$ denotes the inner product defined on the Hilbert Space.

4. (Wave function collapse) If A is an observable with the eigenvalues listed in the set \{ a_{n} \} and the eigenvectors listed in the set \{ \ket{n} \}, and we have a system in a given state \ket{\psi}, the probability of obtaining a_{n} as the “outcome” of the measurement of \mathcal{A} (the physical property corresponding to the observable), i.e. on the action of A on \ket{\psi} is given by,
P(a_{n}) = |\braket{ n | \psi } |^{2}
After such a measurement operation is done, the system is left in the state $\ket{n}$, i.e the wave function $\ket{\psi}$ "collapses" to that state.

5. The time-evolution of a closed system as described in Quantum Mechanics is unitary, i.e. reversible. The evolution is given by the time-dependent Schrodinger equation -
i \hbar \frac{\partial \ket{\psi}}{\partial t} = H \ket{\psi} 
Where $H$ is the **Hamiltonian** of the system, $\hbar$ is the **reduced Planck constant**, and $i$ is $\sqrt{ -1 }$.
